results.headline: Where Performance Enhancers Are Legal
results.summary_short: A rather dull married pharmacist (Sam Rockwell) and a gorgeous, equally married customer (Olivia Wilde) make for an explosive compound in “Better Living Through Chemistry.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Better Living Through Chemistry

results.headline: A Pakistani Fiancé Meets the Indian Parents
results.summary_short: In “Total Siyapaa,” an Indian woman brings her fiancé home to meet her family, a crew that seems more malicious than madcap.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Total Siyapaa

results.headline: Bittersweet Chocolate on the Pillow
results.summary_short: On its surface, “The Grand Budapest Hotel” is a caper, but this Wes Anderson film is also concerned with a complicated slice of 20th-century European culture with some very ugly history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grand Budapest Hotel

results.headline: A Dog and His Boy Take a Joy Ride Through History
results.summary_short: A supersmart dog and his adopted human son set out for time-traveling adventures in “Mr. Peabody & Sherman,” the 3-D, big-screen adaptation of Jay Ward’s animated cartoon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Peabody & Sherman

results.headline: Double Time: Seeing a Ghost, Romantically
results.summary_short: In “The Face of Love,” Annette Bening plays a widow who sees a man, played by Ed Harris, who’s a double for her dead husband.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Face of Love

results.headline: To Scientists in Pursuit, a Bit of Matter Is No Small Matter
results.summary_short: “Particle Fever” is a Mark Levinson documentary that goes into detail about the Higgs boson particle and the structure of the universe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Particle Fever

results.headline: A Heavy Bass Beat, a Wreath of Smoke, an Aura of Sweat
results.summary_short: This film creates a piece of social and sexual history by reshooting segments of the 1980 film “Cruising” that were lost after being cut.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Interior. Leather Bar.

results.headline: A Spiritual Adviser’s Help Is Twisted as He’s Tormented
results.summary_short: “Repentance,” starring Anthony Mackie and Forest Whitaker, examines the price of being a prophet.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Repentance

results.headline: A Juvenile Justice System With Few Checks
results.summary_short: The documentary “Kids for Cash” examines corruption in the juvenile justice system.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kids for Cash

results.headline: The Damage That Good Can Inflict
results.summary_short: “Fatal Assistance,” a documentary by Raoul Peck, chronicles the challenges and failures of rebuilding efforts in Haiti after the 2010 earthquake.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fatal Assistance

results.headline: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
results.summary_short: The Lunchbox,” by Ritesh Batra, puts Old Hollywood style in a Mumbai that has escaped the cyber world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lunchbox

results.headline: If You’d Like to Live, Best Not Look Inside
results.summary_short: “The Bag Man” stars Robert De Niro and John Cusack in a neo-noir about crooks in a cat-and-mouse game.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bag Man

results.headline: Humanity, Enhanced, on a Russian Battlefield
results.summary_short: “Stalingrad” includes two story lines in a narrowly focused 3-D depiction of the struggle for a city during World War II.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stalingrad

results.headline: The Greatest Story, Retold
results.summary_short: Adapted from “The Bible,” a History channel mini-series, “Son of God” depicts the last days of Jesus.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Son of God

results.headline: Eggs Over Easy, With a Side of Weird
results.summary_short: The hero of “Odd Thomas,” an adaptation by Stephen Sommers of the Dean Koontz novel, is a short-order cook who sees dead people and finds their murderers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Odd Thomas

results.headline: An Unreliable Hero Aboard a Troubled Flight
results.summary_short: Liam Neeson stars as an unsettled air marshal trying to prevent murders in the air in “Non-Stop.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Non-Stop

results.headline: So Blissfully Nestled in Her Web of Lies
results.summary_short: The drama “Two Lives,” with Juliane Köhler and Liv Ullmann, focuses on a happily married woman and apparent East German spy whose secrets threaten to destroy her family life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Lives

results.headline: Child Genius Meets Middle-Age Kid
results.summary_short: In “HairBrained,” Brendan Fraser plays a 41-year-old failed gambler who goes back to school and befriends a 14-year-old genius.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of HairBrained

results.headline: A Wasteland, With Aliens
results.summary_short: Joe Begos’s horror movie “Almost Human” should not be confused with the Fox television drama of the same name.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Almost Human

results.headline: Waiting With Bittersweet Anxiety for Their Moment
results.summary_short: The director Stephanie Riggs follows the tribulations of three actors who are on call to step in for a star in a stage show.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Standbys
